verses.text: Then the Lord awoke as from sleep, as a man wakes from the stupor of wine.
He beat back his enemies; he put them to everlasting shame.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:65
rsbNotes.text: 78:65 as from sleep. God had left Israel temporarily and seemed to be asleep. An unusual figure of speech explains how He began to act.

verses.text: Then he rejected the tents of Joseph, he did not choose the tribe of Ephraim;

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:67
rsbNotes.text: 78:67 He rejected. The rejection of the tribe of Ephraim refers to the abandonment of the Shiloh sanctuary, and perhaps also the rejection of Saul’s monarchy.

verses.text: but he chose the tribe of Judah, Mount Zion, which he loved.
He built his sanctuary like the heights, like the earth that he established forever.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:68
rsbNotes.text:
78:68 but he chose the tribe of Judah. Jerusalem succeeded Shiloh as the designated location for the worship of God.

Mount Zion. See note Ps. 2:6.

verses.text: He chose David his servant and took him from the sheep pens;
from tending the sheep he brought him to be the shepherd of his people Jacob, of Israel his inheritance.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:70
rsbNotes.text: 78:70 sheepfolds. This verse recalls David’s humble origins (1 Sam. 16:11–13).

verses.text: And David shepherded them with integrity of heart; with skillful hands he led them.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 78:72
rsbNotes.text: 78:72 upright heart. The psalm climaxes on a positive note with a faithful king in Jerusalem, the place of God’s special presence.
